abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column argues that Argentina's devastating 2001 default on $93 billion in sovereign debt provides strong cautionary tale amid Greek crisis; observes that default led to social unrest, political instability, devalued peso and plunging economy, though nation has recovered considerably since 2002; argues that such a recovery, based on commodity exports, will not be available to Greece, and that default there would be far worse.
lead_paragraph: The Greek debt crisis has similarities to Argentina’s default in 2001. But experts say a default would be much worse for Greece.

headline.main: If Greece Defaults, Imagine Argentina, but Much Worse
headline.print_headline: In Argentina’s Footsteps, Greece Stands to Lose

snippet: The Greek debt crisis has similarities to Argentina’s default in 2001. But experts say a default would be much worse for Greece.
